title: Melbourne footy star admits he was perilously close to suicide
text:
AFL star Shaun Smith has broken down as he revealed he came perilously close to taking his own life by jumping in front of a train as he fought against depression.

The Melbourne and North Melbourne veteran claimed his mental health issues were a direct result of concussions he suffered during his playing days.

Smith, 50, made the admission on SBS Insight on Tuesday alongside fellow great John Barnes as they both sue the AFL for damages their concussions have allegedly caused.

AFL star Shaun Smith has broken down as he revealed he came perilously close to taking his own life by jumping in front of a train as he fought against depression (pictured in his playing days in 2002)

'There was a point where I was at Richmond Station and I was literally half a second away from making a really bad decision,' Smith said.

The twelve-year veteran breathed heavily and appeared to hold back tears as he revealed his struggle to the show's panel of former AFL and NRL stars.

As well as causing depression, Smith also said the repeated blows to the head he suffered during his time in the AFL led to anger management issues.

'I've had a couple of blues where I have punched on with friends and I'm not a fighter. It has cost a friendship recently,' he said.

'I'm ashamed of it but I just couldn't control my anger.'

'All we want is the AFL to say it does cause damage.'

Smith, 50, made the admission on SBS Insight on Tuesday (pictured) alongside fellow great John Barnes as they both sue the AFL for damages their concussions have caused

Barnes, also 50, claimed his head knocks had caused him to develop epilepsy and made him almost completely dependent on his wife Rowena.

'There's probably 7000 past players that need to be tested, a lot of the players from the '60s and '70s who have got the symptoms we've got,' he said.

His wife added their neurologist had made statements that proved his concussion was linked to his epilepsy.

Barnes (pictured), also 50, claimed his head knocks had caused him to develop epilepsy and made him almost completely dependent on his wife Rowena

Barnes has previously revealed was forced to give up his job driving a garbage truck after he had a seizure in 2012.

He said his medication bills run into the hundreds each month, and due to the unpredictability of his condition, he had to give up his driving job.

Since his first epileptic seizure, Barnes said he has become a shadow of his former self, characterised by periods of confusion and unexplained outbursts of rage.

'My temper's pretty short at the moment. The things I find myself doing, I don't really know why I am doing them to be honest,' Barnes told ABC News.

Daily Mail Australia has contacted the AFL for comment.

description: Opening up about his near-death episode, the  Melbourne and North Melbourne AFL veteran claimed his mental health issues were a direct result of concussions he suffered during his playing days.
